awd_titl_txt: The Role of Wave-sea Ice Floe Interactions in Recent Antarctic Sea Ice Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Sea-ice coverage surrounding Antarctica has expanded during the era of satellite observations, in contrast to rapidly shrinking Arctic sea ice. Most climate models predict Antarctic sea ice loss, rather than growth, indicating that there is much to learn about Antarctic sea ice in terms of its natural variability, processes and interactions affecting annual growth and retreat, and the impact of atmospheric factors such increasing greenhouse gases and stratospheric ozone depletion.  This project is designed to improve model simulations of sea ice and examine the role of wind and wave forcing on changes in sea ice around Antarctica.

This project seeks to explain basic interactions of the coupled atmosphere, ocean, and ice dynamics in the Antarctic climate system, especially in the region near the sea ice edge.  The summer evolution of sea ice cover and the near surface heat exchange of atmosphere and ocean depend on the geometric distribution of floes and the open water surrounding them. The distribution of floes has the greatest impact on the sea ice state in the marginal seas, where the distribution itself can vary rapidly. This project would develop and implement a model of sea ice floes in the Los Alamos sea ice model, known as CICE5. This sea ice component would be coupled to the third generation WaveWatch model within the Community Climate System Model Version 2. The coupled model would be used to study sea ice-wave interactions and the role of modeling sea ice floes in the Antarctic.  The broader impacts of this project include outreach, support of female scientists, and improvement of the sea-ice codes in widely used climate models.

por.por_cntn:
The marginal ice zone (MIZ) is the region of sea ice-covered ocean that is strongly influenced by open ocean processes, especially by surface waves. Simulating the MIZ poses a particular challenge for the prediction of sea ice extent and thickness.  The melt and growth of sea ice and the near surface heat exchange of atmosphere and ocean depend on the geometric distribution of floes and the open water surrounding them. The distribution of floes has the greatest impact on the sea ice state in the MIZ, where the distribution itself is most likely to be evolving rapidly. Ocean mixing near the surface from waves is important in the MIZ. Before our project, the propagation of waves into sea ice and the subsequent wave attenuation by sea ice was not simulated in models used to study and predict climate. The primary goal of this project was to simulate wind effects on the Antarctic MIZ more faithfully in a global climate model, so the role of wind changes on Antarctic sea ice and the Southern Ocean can be better understood.

A primary objective was to simulate the sea ice floe-size distribution and the role of waves on floe fracture and sea ice formation. Fractured sea ice has a larger perimeter to area ratio, so fractured sea ice can experience proportionately higher lateral (sidewall) to bottom melt than unfractured sea ice. We implemented a floe-size distribution in the Los Alamos sea ice model, known as CICE. We added a new attenuation scheme to a wave model, the third-generation WAVE-WATCH WW3 model, and improved WW3's numerical accuracy for wave attenuation in sea ice. We first investigated these code developments in reduced-order models.

When satisfied with the code behavior in reduced-order models, we coupled the sea ice and wave models together in the developmental Community Earth System Model Version 2.3 (CESM2.3). We ran a suite of experiments to investigate the response of the climate to sea ice-wave interactions and we evaluated the wave energy spectrum simulated in the model with mooring data. Figure 1 demonstrates three key quantities that interact in our simulations. Waves are generated primarily outside of the sea ice zone, where the sea ice fraction is zero. The significant wave height (the height of the 1/3 most energetic waves) is typically several meters and can be more than 10 m during stormy weather. Figure 1 shows a typical day. Wave heights damp as wave propagate into the sea ice and generally are 1 m or smaller. Floe sizes tend to be small (a few meters or smaller) further away from the Antarctic continent, where the waves are highest. Floes are less fractured and hence larger near the continent, where most of the wave energy has been damped away. The parameterization for wave attenuation that we added to the wave model accounts for floe sizes such that floes smaller than the wavelength tend to tip without flexing - so they cause more modest attenuation. In contrast, floes larger than the wavelength tend to flex in high waves. The model accounts for floe flexure, which damps the waves and can fracture floes if severe enough. 

Figure 2 illustrates that lateral and basal melt rates in summer are strongly influenced by floe size in our simulations. With sea ice-wave interactions, floes are highly fractured and there is a greater perimeter of floes. The total amount of lateral and bottom melted is controlled by the heat content of the upper ocean. With a greater perimeter, more of the heat content causes lateral melt. The total lateral plus bottom melt is higher for the simulation with the sea ice-wave interactions because higher rates of lateral melt enhance sea ice-albedo feedback and more sunlight is absorbed in the upper ocean. Consequently, the simulation with the sea ice-wave interactions has lower sea ice concentration in January. The preference for lateral over bottom melt occurs year-round in the simulation with the sea ice-wave interactions, but it is less extreme when there is less sunlight.

This project developed a new sea ice floe-size distribution and coupled sea ice-wave capability for a widely-used climate model. As the developments are used for future production runs, the role of sea ice and waves on Antarctic sea ice trends in the past and future can be explored.
